results.title: Drop kick eulogy
results.brief_description:
A couple of Rupanyup stalwarts recount the days when the drop kick was king, before the invention of the more reliable but less skillful ‘drop punt’.

Thank you to Bob Baker, Jack Dunlop, Dawn Teasdale and the Rupanyup Football Club. Archival film by John Teasdale.

TRANSCRIPT

[MEN SHOUTING]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

BOB BAKER: I’d say it was about 1950, I started. And in those days, it was either a dropkick or a torp. And of course, the high-mark blokes always went crook if you weren’t kicking a dropkick, because they’d have a lark making torpedo kicks.

The blokes who kicked good dropkicks were worth watching, but a lot of us, myself included, weren’t good dropkicks. And dropkicks were a problem because the ground, the surface changed. And OK, the natural base could always get away. But all the same, every now and again, you’d go to a different ground. Like you’d go up to the sandy ground up at Jeparit and even our best fellows would kick a grounder occasionally.

[CROWD CHEERING]

JACK DUNLOP: I loved it, actually. We were always doing it, from the time we first went to school. Because the drop punt had never been thought of when I gave it away. So we fancied it as a distance kick, on fine days. You didn’t do it on a wind day.

Mainly the biggest thing with dropkicking was timing. If you didn’t time it, it didn’t go anywhere. But no, in later years, we had some pretty good big men, good high marks here. And your ambition was to get it as far as you could. They had a fair idea how far you could kick it, and you would kick to a contest. Not like today, where they won’t kick to a contest at all.

[MEN SHOUTING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

Those days, when they really used it, they all took their marks, went back and had their shots at goal and that. And they’d take up here but top it behind the head like this. Nobody ever does that these days.

When you take a mark, you’ve got the ball. You’re got to have your ball in your hand ready, because there might be a handball or something. And those sort of things went out in the early ‘50s.

ONLOOKER: Let fly, Richie!

BOB BAKER: Well, every coach I had tried to teach me how to kick dropkicks, and I never really mastered dropkicks. I remember playing one day and Jim Gulley was coaching, and I was playing center halfback. And Gulley didn’t mind me kicking them, because everyone else thought I’d kick them further than I did. And Gulley would lead up the ground and the center halfback wouldn’t follow him, because he thought he was getting too close to me. But that’s as far as I could kick the jolly things.

[MEN SHOUTING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

Nowadays with the drop punt, everyone kicks a drop punt and the balls so easy to handle. It doesn’t matter which leg you’re kicking. You’ve still got the ball in the same position to kick it. And it’s made a lot of difference to football, the drop punt, has. It’s one of the biggest challenges in the whole lot, I’d say.

results.title: Drop dead gorgeous
results.creator_credit: Capella, KC Medien, New Line Cinema, Gavin Polone, Judy Hofflund and Michael Patrick Jann
results.brief_description: Set in small town America, “Drop dead gorgeous” is a satire about teen beauty contests, ambitious parents and urban dysfunction. As the citizens of Mount Rose, Minnesota gear up for the Sarah Rose Miss Teen Princess America Pageant, the proceedings are filmed by a documentary crew, lending the film its mockumentary structure. The main contestants are Becky Leeman, whose ambitious mother runs the beauty contest and Amber Atkins, a plucky and talented working class teen who lives in a trailer park with her depressed alcoholic mother. When various contestants die in an array of mysterious circumstances Amber suspects that her life is in danger if she stays in competition. This film takes a savage view of American societal mores, as it mocks small town values, beauty contests, marriage, alcoholism, obesity, anorexia, paedophiles, handicapped people, mother-daughter relationships and the gauche self-consciousness of teenagers. It gladly follows in the footsteps of “Waiting for Guffman” and “Spinal tap”, but never reaches the hilarity of such predecessors, possibly due to its good natured and loveable heroine, contrasting too starkly with hideous caricatures. At times the black humour and merciless ridiculing of the screenplay are uncomfortable to watch, defiantly crossing over into bad taste on numerous occasions.

results.title: Driving: risks and responsibilities
results.brief_description: Cars have become an essential tool in most businesses and the risks and responsibilities associated with driving on the job are the primary focus of this program. Outlines the costs incurred to businesses when a car accident occurs, the benefits of a safe driving program and safe driving policy, as well as basic practices to ensure the safety of the driver, other road users, pedestrians and the car itself. Useful as a basic guide to vehicle safety for the instruction of new and learner drivers.

results.title: Driving without tears
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Hector Lemieux
results.brief_description: We accompany a driving instructor to see how the City of Vancouver trains expert and responsible motorists. Shows how a driving school gives both theoretical and practical teaching on all the intricacies of city and highway traffic. The film includes reference to training programs in secondary schools to make teenagers better drivers.

results.title: Driving to a system
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “How to Drive”.
The drills of the system of car control demonstrated have been well tried and are well proven; once memorised and understood, the system soon becomes an almost instinctive routine. The system is designed to ensure that at all times the car is in the right place on the road, travelling at the right speed for existing conditions, in the right gear, and the driver is never trying to do more than one thing at a time.

results.title: Driving Miss Daisy
results.creator_credit: Zanuck Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Richard Zanuck, Lili Zanuck and Bruce Beresford
results.brief_description: The funny, touching and totally irresistible story of a working relationship that became a twenty-five year friendship. When Daisy Werthan (Jessica Tandy) crashes her car, her son Boolie (Dan Ackroyd) insists that his mother’s driving days are over. He hires a chauffeur for her, Hoke Colburn (Morgan Freeman) to keep her out of trouble. But feisty Daisy resents the intrusion and she almost drives Hoke crazy with her insistence that she doesn’t need his help. Luckily, Hoke is a very patient man and the pair become the best of friends after 25 years of driving together. Winner of 4 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Actress. Screenplay by Alfred Uhry based on his play.

results.title: Driving home
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Susan Kim
results.brief_description: A young Asian girl, a recent migrant, recalls driving in her new homeland. A metaphor for the migrant experience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts and Susan Kim

results.title: Driving home
results.brief_description:
A child is being driven through a real and imaginary landscape. We experience her subtle turmoil as she tries to make sense of these worlds.
This beautiful animation depicts the sense of disorientation and isolation felt by a young girl who is a recent immigrant of Australia. The quintessentially Australian backdrop of the wide open road serves to add to her mental and physical unease. The emotional confusion that is expressed in the narrative is realised perfectly in the shifting, sweeping motion of the oil paint animation. MIFF 2000

results.title: Drivers in Court
results.brief_description: Brian and Alex are both in court pleading guilty to similar speeding charges. Brian, unlike Alex, knows what to expect and what to say. The magistrate gives Brian a bond but Alex loses his licence.
results.description: Brian and Alex are both in court pleading guilty to similar speeding charges. Brian, unlike Alex, knows what to expect and what to say. The magistrate gives Brian a bond but Alex loses his licence.

results.title: Drivers I have known and hated
results.brief_description: Looks at some of the most aggravating and dangerous drivers on the roads today and identifies many frustrating and hazardous situations caused by drivers with poor attitudes. Inspires viewers to examine their own driving habits.
